DUTIES OF OFFICERS

Page

Table of Contents

 

Managing director convicted for safety breach

 

In 2012, the managing director of a plastics recycling company was convicted and fined $25,000 for breaching WHS laws.

 

James Chung was the managing director at Rexma. His responsibilities included managing operations, instructing employees and developing procedures for the work undertaken at the plant. Mr Chung was charged after an unsafe machine amputated an employer’s fingers.

 

Mr Chung explained to the court that he had advised employees to turn off power to the machine before removing the machine’s guard. However, the court stated that this was not an adequate safety precaution, as employees regularly took shortcuts in order to keep machines running. The case highlights the importance of taking reasonable steps for officers involved in the management of a company.

 

What is considered reasonable will depend on the circumstances, including the role and influence that an officer is able to exercise. Some factors for consideration include:

 

•

what duties the PCBU owes

•

the position, responsibilities and authority of the officer and what is reasonable in the circumstances

•

the nature of risks to health and safety posed by the particular business or undertaking

BE CAREFUL

 

If an officer relies on information, advice or the expertise of others in the course of their due diligence obligations, they must be able to demonstrate that their reliance was reasonable.

 

Managing director convicted for safety breach
